name: iron sinter production | iron sinter | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/22991/documentation

"Background:;;This activity produces iron sinter for use in the blast furnace. The goal of the sintering process is to improve the permeability and reducability of the blast furnace charge, a mixture of fine ores, coke breeze, additives (e.g. lime) and iron-bearing materials that are returned from downstream iron and steemaking operations. Raw materials are blended together in a mixing drum and then placed on a conveyor belt on top of a layer of recycled sinter. The sinter mixture is moved slowly along a continuously moving grate with acombustion front drawing downwards through the mixture, which sinters the fine particles together. ;;Modelling approach: ;Data on were mostly taken from the IPPC Best Available Technology report from the European Commission (Remus et al., 2013); note that where only data ranges were provided, the geometric mean of reported values was used here. The amounts of iron-bearing materials returned from downstream activities are based on the amount of each respective material that is produced and sent for internal recycling according to worldsteel (2010). It should be noted that data on radionucleid emissions to air, e.g. of Pollonium 210 and Lead 210, were not available and have therefore not been inventoried here.;;References:;Remus, R., Aguado-Monsonet, M. A., Roudier, S. & Samcho, L. D. (2013). JRC reference report - Best available techniques (BAT) reference document for iron and steel production. Joint Research Centre - European Commission, Luxemboug. ;Worldsteel (2010). Steel industry by-products. World Steel Association: Brussels, Belgium."

At the gate of the integrated sintering-blast furnace plant.

With the mixed, sintered iron-bearing mixture being ready for charging in the blast furnace.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/241:Manufacture of basic iron and steel/2410:Manufacture of basic iron and steel

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are mostly compiled from reports published between 2007 and 2010 but are considered representative of modern operations.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data are representative of the average sitaution in Europe, with the exception of the amounts of iron-bearing material returns, which are based on average global statistics.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Represents average European technology; down draft sintering on continuous travelling grates.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Most data were taken from direct measurements at five sinter plants in Europe; data on the amounts of iron-bearing return materials based on measured data from plants worldwide.

Difference of "Dusts" and "PM10" as reported by Remus et al. The emissions refer to production steps of (1) Blending and mixing, (3) Sinter strand, (4) Secondary dedusting and (5) Sinter coolling.

Reference: Remus, R., Aguado-Monsonet, M. A., Roudier, S., Samcho, L. D. , 2013, JRC reference report - Best available techniques (BAT) reference document for iron and steel production, Luxemboug, JRC - European Commission, 3 - SeparatePublication

geometric mean of Remus et al. (2013) data range

86% of "PM10" reported in Remus et al. (geometric mean), split (86%) based on the values from EMEP/EEA. The emissions refer to production steps of (1) Blending and mixing, (3) Sinter strand, (4) Secondary dedusting and (5) Sinter coolling.

Reference: EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook 2019: Iron and steel production Processes.
Remus, R., Aguado-Monsonet, M. A., Roudier, S., Samcho, L. D. , 2013, JRC reference report - Best available techniques (BAT) reference document for iron and steel production, Luxemboug, JRC - European Commission, 3 - SeparatePublication.
